positive.review:
Aight so lemme be clear, I love this game, I put in 600 hours and I'll put in a thousands more. I'm not going to quit until its dead. There's been a handful of other games that try to be like it but none of them have the same level of polish or depth. The mechanics are extremely well thought out and every character feels unique.

God damn though this game needs to treat new players better. They basically cant queue ranked without a premade, and that can be hard to get when a decent portion of the playerbase is too high of a rank to queue with them. There are a lot of mechanics that aren't explained very well or are not explained at all despite being extremely important, and you'll have to spend hours digging through discord, old reddit threads, and youtube to learn about them. 

There's also a lot of inconsistencies due to the low tick rate of the servers. This has been a problem for a long time and sometimes it makes the game really suck to play. The CN server runs like 6x faster than NA, even with a VPN at 200 MS, it felt more consistent than 30 MS on NA/Global. I know you have the money, I see the people running around with every skin in the game, just upgrade the servers already, shit dude I'd pay for it myself if I wasn't just some dude with a normal job.

Other than that though, I love the game and I want to see more people on it. Better onboarding and a tiny server upgrade would go so far.

Not part of the review, but please for the love of god ignore anyone complaining about CN/SEA/SA/EU players on NA. There's like a 99% chance that the Chinese dude is living and going to school/working in North America, there's no reason to play on NA if you (normally) have access to CN servers. You also have such a massive disadvantage with high ping that if you're losing to a SEA/SA/EU player, you're probably just worse than them.

Still the most unique BR available. It has its flaws which will be addressed below but lets start with clearing up some misconceptions/outdated information regarding the game. The most obvious deterrent for potential new players to even install the game is that it requires HVCI to be turned off. While this was true when Windows 11 was new, this requirement was removed via an update several months later. HVCI is no longer required to be turned off as of this review and all other reviews that mentioned this issue are either outdated or just trolling. Next, there are claims that the game is infested with hackers (some reviews claim up to 90% of players are hacking). This is completely false. I have spent over 3k hours in the game and the number of people that were hacking/using some exploit can be counted on one hand. There definitely are players who still use hacks/find exploits but they are a small fraction of the playerbase (the same can be said with any other BR). The devs also publish weekly banned players lists to remove hackers and keep such behaviour in check.

With the misconceptions out of the way, lets move on to the negatives. First of all, the playerbase in the West (NA/EU servers) is tiny compared to Asia (SEA/AS servers). If you play on SEA/AS servers, kindly skip to the next paragraph as matchmaking is not an issue. For NA/EU servers, most new players will only be playing against bots (and winning most matches) in ranked mode until Solar. Assuming that they have the patience to reach Solar, newbies will then be placed in lobbies with top server players and proceed to be obliterated by them. Such matchmaking is understandably frustrating for new players as the learning curve can seem too steep. This is the point where newbies quit because they are demolished by veterans almost every match past Solar rank. Personally, I have also experienced this when I was new to the game so all I can say to new players is: Stay patient & "Get Good". Participate in custom lobbies to learn Neutral/combos/movement tech and you will be able to put up a fight against good players eventually. 

Another negative is the abysmal server disconnects during games, especially in crowded areas/endgame fights. These can vary in severity from being mildly annoying to causing the match to be lost. These glitches can happen quite often too, sometimes a few times during every match on bad days. You will experience screen stutters in mild cases, to seeing the screen buffer icon while the screen freezes and tries to reconnect to servers in worse cases. There is also the less common but potentially game breaking bug where you are sent back to the login screen during a match if you use certain hero skills, such as Tianhai's combo breaker F skill. As of writing this, the hero skill bug seems to be fixed but I will update this review if it happens again.

Finally, I shall address positives after all that doom and gloom. From all the previous points mentioned, you may think that all the drawbacks outweigh the positives, but I beg to differ. This is hands down the most unique BR available. Its depth of combat and movement mechanics is unmatched by any other modern game of its genre. Fights against real players are satisfying regardless of outcome once you have learnt the basics of Neutral/True Combos/Scalerushing. In a world where most if not all new games try to make you feel like a champion, this game constantly reminds you of your shortcomings in skill. You will lose way more than you win until you "get good". You will need to earn your wins which in turn feel much more fulfilling. I would also like to mention that there is a PvE mode called Showdown which is similar to Souls-like games and an extraction mode called Rift Traversal for those looking for something other than the BR. I highly recommend trying Showdown if the BR/PvP is not your cup of tea as boss fights there are just as challenging and fulfilling at the highest difficulty.

In conclusion, Naraka stands out as a unique melee-based BR experience in a sea of shooter BRs. 
Is it perfect? No.
Does it have technical issues? Yes. Sometimes.
Is it challenging but fulfilling to learn and improve? Absolutely.
Is it fun? Hell yea.
More importantly, is it worth your time? Find out for yourself.

Extremely competitive melee-focused battle royale based on Chinese mythology. Great online community and fun, unique, endlessly customizable characters. The massive variety in skills, weapons, outfits, hairstyles, accessories, individual abilities and more makes the player customization in this game one of the best. Also some of the best looking playable characters in any competitive game. The ranking system is well-designed, and the maps are beautiful tp play in. There is such a wide variety of modes to play, with my favorite being ranked Solos, Duos and Trios. However, there IS a casual mode to choose, with a plethora of different game-modes for un-ranked play. This game has so much to offer I can't even begin to write it all in this one review(: There are also PvE modes that are available in solo or co-op, with challenging bosses, utilizing an entirely different ranking system and skill progression than the PvP modes. This game has something for any gamer, and I very much recommend playing if you want a game that is both rewarding to play as well as highly competitive. 10/10 game

The game completely reimagines the battle royale formula by focusing on fast-paced, skill-based melee combat, parkour, and a wuxia-inspired aesthetic. It's a breath of fresh air in a genre dominated by shooters. The rock-paper-scissors-style combat system (normal attacks, parries, charged attacks) is deep and incredibly satisfying to master. It feels more like a fighting game than a typical battle royale. The Eastern fantasy art style is beautiful, and character designs are full of personality.

This is a quality game that doesn't require skill to play. You can play both solo and in teams. There are many game modes to choose from. You can play with bots if you don't want to fight with others. But be careful of Smurfs. Even low-level players may be new or don't play often, but sometimes high-level players want to hit newbies for fun. But don't worry, it's not limited to this game. Smurfs are everywhere, in every game. Have fun and good luck.

Quick thing I want to mention before I get into the meat of my review. Another Steam User has claimed that the game requires you to disable HVCI. Upon starting the game, I did not have such an alert show up, BUT I did notice part of my Core Isolation stuff was disabled due to Easy Anti-Cheat (Which this game doesn't use, from what I can tell). If you have EAC, odds are high that whatever Narakas Anti-Cheat needs disabled is already disabled by EAC.

Okay, so. When I first was considering Naraka, I was on the fence. I didn't really want to get sunk into ANOTHER Battle Royale, as I've kinda checked out of most BRs, these days. That said, Naraka is... weirdly enough, a breath of fresh air. The melee focused approach to it is certainly an interesting idea that I do not hate, but I am also speaking from the perspective of someone who has only played vs AI in the dedicated bot lobby mode. 

Speaking of that, A vs AI/Bot Lobby mode that allows full progression of the game should be the norm nowadays, with how overly competitive games have gotten. Between some players just naturally getting better quicker than others, and the SBMM systems just not working (most of the time), I have enjoyed most of the matches against the AI, and it allows me to just chill and relax, be it on my own, or while in a discord call with friends. I will not speak on the regular BR, as I have no intentions on touching it, seeing as I can play the game the way I want to and still get rewarded as much as others.

Now, onto Showdown, the PvE mode. Its... interesting. On one hand, I wish the missions were longer and had a more cohesive story, but the more I thought about it, the more I didn't mind them being short. It reminds me of mobile games and their incredibly short levels, BUT without the horrendous stamina system that basically prevents you for playing for longer than you want to. I also love how the ranged gameplay was also changed to be just as satisfying as the melee gameplay.

I have not tried the Extraction Shooter gamemode, as I am not a fan of that genre at all (mainly because every single one that has existed is a PvPvE one, and I'm not really into PvP games as a whole, anymore), so I will not be speaking on it. 

As for cosmetics, its a typical Eastern made game, so most high rarity cosmetics are going to show more skin or be very extravagant. If you're into that, I don't judge. My only gripe on the cosmetic part is the fact a lot of cosmetics from Hidden Treasures (The Battle Pass) are seemingly never coming back. But, this is an issue that plagues every live action game nowadays, so I'm not going to hold it against the devs too much. I will say, one thing that I have to praise the devs for is the ability to completely change a characters facial features (For the most part, there is one character that cannot be altered, due to the fact they are a collab character). Being able to use one character as a basis for another character I want to bring into the game is amazing, and I'm glad it is an option.

From my initial perspective, Naraka Bladepoint is a pretty fun game with a fair amount of stuff to do that I'm glad a friend recommended to me. Hopefully it continues to improve as time goes on.

When it released the game had an amazing potential and was a fresh breeze to all kinds of battle-royale games. It offered an unique medieval/fantasy style combat and good content that hooked me into playing that game. Unfortunetly throughout the last 2 years 24E and NetEase somehow managed to make only bad decisions and mishandled the game to the point where EU/NA/SEA community is almost not existent. Let the player numbers not fool you. The great majority of playerbase shown are CN players. The rest of the regions can get up to 2k active players at best during rush hours. 24E completely failed with the game's advertisements and appeal to western players. There was simply none to begin with. The big f2p update was a complete flop on many levels. Ignoring core problems of the game in terms of balancing or matchmaking killed player retention where no new players are joining and the ones that do join are thrown into bot matches or later on straight into the grasp of veteran players (because they are the only ones still playing the game somehow). Shortly after those players leave because of pure frustration. Game also had pretty good monetization system where you could buy the battlepass one time and get the next ones for free by completing the previous ones (still has it). Devs also managed to fumble that by adding more and more predatory things each big update (more fomo, gacha chests, spliting bp into two (pvp and pve), locking certain cosmetics into overpriced bundles and so on, and so on. Overall as for now I recommend everyone to stay away from that game....period. Naraka unfortunetly became one of those symbols of wasted potential and it really had good one.

When it released the game had an amazing potential and was a fresh breeze to all kinds of battle-royale games. It offered an unique medieval/fantasy style combat and good content that hooked me into playing that game. Unfortunetly throughout the last 2 years 24E and NetEase somehow managed to make only bad decisions and mishandled the game to the point where EU/NA/SEA community is almost not existent. Let the player numbers not fool you. The great majority of playerbase shown are CN players. The rest of the regions can get up to 2k active players at best during rush hours. 24E completely failed with the game's advertisements and appeal to western players. There was simply none to begin with. The big f2p update was a complete flop on many levels. Ignoring core problems of the game in terms of balancing or matchmaking killed player retention where no new players are joining and the ones that do join are thrown into bot matches or later on straight into the grasp of veteran players (because they are the only ones still playing the game somehow). Shortly after those players leave because of pure frustration. Game also had pretty good monetization system where you could buy the battlepass one time and get the next ones for free by completing the previous ones (still has it). Devs also managed to fumble that by adding more and more predatory things each big update (more fomo, gacha chests, spliting bp into two (pvp and pve), locking certain cosmetics into overpriced bundles and so on, and so on. Overall as for now I recommend everyone to stay away from that game....period. Naraka unfortunetly became one of those symbols of wasted potential and it really had good one.
